bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to James Carroll, November 8, 1900

div1.p: Howard provides information to Carroll about a certain species of mosquito. Howard then asks Carroll to catch a species of mosquito for his own research, which is believed to have migrated to Cuba in slave ships years ago. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to James Carroll, November 8, 1900
div1.p:
The mosquito which you handed me the day before
you left is Culex pungens. You will remember that this is the
specimen in the vial with cotton.

I am busily engaged just now in writing up a paper on the
insect fauna of human excrement and it occurs to me that you may
possibly have an opportunity in Havana of collecting flies, either
in privies (if they have such things in Cuba) or attracted to
chance deposits. Of course I realize that you are down there
for one purpose and that all your energy will be devoted to
that work, but if you should have a chance to get some of these
flies for me, or if you know someone down there who will do it,
I shall be very glad indeed to get the specimens. There is one
little excrement fly which is interesting in this connection,
namely, Borborus venalicius. It is an African species and is
said to have been brought to Cuba in slave ships many years ago.
It has never been found in the United States and we have no
specimens in the National Museum. It may, however, be one of
the commonest species in Cuba. It is one of the small, dark-
colored flies which are always seen about fresh excrement. The
best way to catch these things is to have a very small hand net
made. If you think it worth while I will send you a small net
and a cyanide bottle. If you have no time and do not care to
